questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast ID, and First/Last Usable Host for Host IP: 10.0.20.5 with Mask: 255.0.0.0
questions.explanation: This is a Class A default mask (/8). The first octet is the network portion, and the remaining three are the host portion.
questions.answer: Network ID: 10.0.0.0, Broadcast ID: 10.255.255.255, First Host: 10.0.0.1, Last Host: 10.255.255.254

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast ID, and First/Last Usable Host for Host IP: 172.200.10.5 with Mask: 255.255.0.0
questions.explanation: This is a Class B default mask (/16). The first two octets represent the network.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast ID, and First/Last Usable Host for Host IP: 192.168.20.73 with Mask: 255.255.255.240
questions.explanation: The mask 240 (/28) has a block size of 16. Multiples of 16 include 64 and 80. Since .73 falls between them, the network is .64.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast ID, and First/Last Usable Host for Host IP: 192.168.2.33 with Mask: 255.255.255.248
questions.explanation: The mask 248 (/29) has a block size of 8. Multiples of 8 include 32 and 40. Since .33 falls in this range, the network is .32.
questions.answer: Network ID: 192.168.2.32, Broadcast ID: 192.168.2.39, First Host: 192.168.2.33, Last Host: 192.168.2.38

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast ID, and First/Last Usable Host for Host IP: 172.16.20.19 with Mask: 255.255.240.0
questions.explanation: The mask 240.0 (/20) has a block size of 16 in the third octet. Multiples are 0, 16, 32. Since the third octet is 20, the network starts at 16.0.
questions.answer: Network ID: 172.16.16.0, Broadcast ID: 172.16.31.255, First Host: 172.16.16.1, Last Host: 172.16.31.254

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address: 192.168.10.0 into 5 Subnets.
questions.explanation: To get at least 5 subnets, we need to borrow 3 bits ($2^3 = 8$). Adding 3 bits to the default Class C mask (/24) gives /27.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address: 10.0.0.0 into 5 Subnets.
questions.explanation: Borrowing 3 bits from the default Class A mask (/8) results in a /11 prefix.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address: 172.16.0.0 into 5 Subnets.
questions.explanation: Borrowing 3 bits from the default Class B mask (/16) results in a /19 prefix.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address: 192.168.1.0 into 4 Subnets.
questions.explanation: To get exactly 4 subnets, we borrow 2 bits ($2^2 = 4$). /24 + 2 = /26.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address: 192.168.1.0 into 7 Subnets.
questions.explanation: To get 7 subnets, we must borrow 3 bits ($2^3 = 8$), resulting in /27.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address: 192.0.2.50 into 5 Subnets.
questions.explanation: Assuming the base network is 192.0.2.0/24, borrowing 3 bits gives /27.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address: 198.51.100.200 into 5 Subnets.
questions.explanation: Assuming the base network is 198.51.100.0/24, borrowing 3 bits gives /27.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address for hosts: 216.21.5.0 into 30 Hosts.
questions.explanation: For 30 hosts, we need 5 host bits ($2^5 - 2 = 30$). 32 - 5 = /27.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address for hosts: 172.16.0.0 into 120 Hosts.
questions.explanation: For 120 hosts, we need 7 host bits ($2^7 - 2 = 126$). 32 - 7 = /25.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address for hosts: 10.1.0.0 into 500 Hosts.
questions.explanation: For 500 hosts, we need 9 host bits ($2^9 - 2 = 510$). 32 - 9 = /23.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address for hosts: 196.10.20.0 into 52 Hosts.
questions.explanation: For 52 hosts, we need 6 host bits ($2^6 - 2 = 62$). 32 - 6 = /26.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address for hosts: 150.15.0.0 into 500 Hosts.
questions.explanation: For 500 hosts, we need 9 host bits ($2^9 - 2 = 510$). 32 - 9 = /23.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address for hosts: 192.168.1.0 into 50 Hosts.
questions.explanation: For 50 hosts, we need 6 host bits ($2^6 - 2 = 62$). 32 - 6 = /26.

questions.q: Subnet the following Network IP address for hosts: 150.15.0.0 into 500 Hosts (Repeated).
questions.explanation: Duplicate of question 5.

questions.q: Subnet 201.1.1.0 to accommodate 40 Hosts.
questions.explanation: To support 40 hosts, we need 6 bits ($2^6 - 2 = 62$). This results in a /26 prefix.

questions.q: Subnet 170.15.0.0 to accommodate 1000 Hosts.
questions.explanation: To support 1000 hosts, we need 10 bits ($2^{10} - 2 = 1022$). This results in a /22 prefix.

questions.q: Subnet 15.0.0.0 to accommodate 100 Hosts.
questions.explanation: To support 100 hosts, we need 7 bits ($2^7 - 2 = 126$). This results in a /25 prefix.

questions.q: Subnet 10.0.0.0 to accommodate 100 Hosts.
questions.explanation: Similar to the previous question, 100 hosts requires 7 bits, resulting in a /25 prefix.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast, First Host, and Last Host for: 192.168.20.73 /28
questions.explanation: /28 has an increment of 16. The multiple of 16 before 73 is 64.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast, First Host, and Last Host for: 172.16.5.34 /26
questions.explanation: /26 has an increment of 64. The multiple of 64 before 34 is 0.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast, First Host, and Last Host for: 172.20.45.200 /20
questions.explanation: /20 has an increment of 16 in the 3rd octet. Multiples: 0, 16, 32, 48. 45 falls in the 32 block.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast, First Host, and Last Host for: 203.0.113.197 /26
questions.explanation: /26 has an increment of 64. Multiples: 0, 64, 128, 192. 197 falls in the 192 block.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast, First Host, and Last Host for: 172.16.5.130 /16
questions.explanation: /16 is a Class B boundary. The first two octets stay the same, the rest are host bits.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast, First Host, and Last Host for: 10.15.20.30 /8
questions.explanation: /8 is a Class A boundary. Only the first octet is the network portion.

questions.q: Find the Network ID, Broadcast, First Host, and Last Host for: 192.168.1.100 /24
questions.explanation: /24 is a Class C boundary. The first three octets stay the same.
